revision.text:
'''Cristián Parker''' (born November 1953) Chilean sociologist, specialist in Latin America's [[sociology of religion]]. Ph D. in Sociology, [[Université Catholique de Louvain]] and Licentiate in Sociology ([[Universidad Católica de Chile]]). Full professor at the [[Universidad de Santiago de Chile]], researcher at the Institute for Advanced Studies ([[Instituto de Estudios Avanzados (Universidad de Santiago de Chile)|Instituto de Estudios Avanzados]]), and Director of the Master in Social Sciences with major in Civil Society Studies program.<ref>{{cite web|last1=IDEA|title=Investigadores IDEA. C. Parker|url=http://ideausach.cl/index.php/investigadores/207-cristian-parker|website=Instituto de Estudios Avanzados|accessdate=29 August 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151207211624/http://ideausach.cl/index.php/investigadores/207-cristian-parker|archivedate=7 December 2015|df=}}</ref> One of his major works is Popular Religion and Modernization in Latin America (Orbis) with Spanish and Portuguese versions.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Kate|first1=John|title=Book Reviews|journal=Anglican Theological Review|date=1998|volume=80|issue=2|page=297}}</ref>
==Academic background== His academic background includes different universities, such as Universidad Católica de Chile and Université Catholique de Louvain, where he got his training; Universidad Academia de Humanismo Cristiano and Universidad de Santiago de Chile, where he has worked preferentially.
During his academic career he has contributed to the sociology of religion and culture, publishing various works in this field of knowledge.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Blasi|first1=Anthony|title=Sociology of Religion Searchable Bibliographic Database|url=http://www.thearda.com/rrh/resources/citations.asp?searchterms=cristi%E1n+parker&incTitle=T&incAuthor=T&incAnnotation=T&incPubInfo=T&incBooks=T&incPublications=T&incTheses=T&incDissertations=T&pubStartYear=&pubEndYear=&p=Z&c=ZABCDEF&m=50&sf=Citations&t=Search+Citations&pg=citations.asp|website=Association of Religion Data Archives|accessdate=29 August 2015}}</ref> In 1993 he published a book on popular religions and modernization in Latin America, under the title “Otra Lógica en América Latina, Religión popular y modernización capitalista”<ref>{{cite book|last1=Parker|first1=Cristián|title=Otra Lógica en América Latina, Religión popular y modernización capitalista|date=1996|publisher=Fondo de Cultura Económica|location=Santiago y México|isbn=9567083088|pages=407}}</ref> He has authored or coautored 22 books and 81 book chapters and 91 publications in scientific journals; he has also given conferences in no less than 15 Chilean universities and in 30 universities in America, Europe and Asia (258 presentations or conferences).<ref>{{cite web|last1=Parker|first1=Cristián|title=Curriculum Vitae|url=http://media.wix.com/ugd/c6b930_d8da955aeffc4ae9bfcdc1b4fcff1727.pdf|website=Parker Sociologo|accessdate=29 August 2015}}</ref>
He has been Director of the School of Sociology, Dean of Social Science (1989-1995) at the [[Universidad Academia de Humanismo Cristiano]], and then he was Vice-president of Research and Development (2002-2003) and Director of the [[:es:Instituto de Estudios Avanzados (Universidad de Santiago de Chile)|Institute for Advanced Studies]] of the Universidad de Santiago de Chile (2005- 2010). He has been a consultant for [[UNICEF]], [[UNDP]], [[ECLAC]], FLACSO-Ecuador, and various public agencies in Chile, among them ministries of Education, of Development and Justice. In addition he has lectured in Research Methodology in the Academia Diplomática de Chile (2004-2012) and the Master's program in Military History and Strategic Thought of the War Academy of the Chilean Army (2004-2015)<ref>{{cite web|last1=Parker|first1=Cristián|title=Bio / CV|url=http://www.parkersociologo.com/|website=Parker Sociologo|accessdate=29 August 2015}}</ref>
==Contributions to Sociology== It has been stated <ref>{{cite book|last1=Cipriani|first1=Roberto|title=Manual de Sociología de la Religión|date=2011|publisher=Siglo Veintiuno Editores|location=Buenos Aires|isbn=978-987-629-194-1|page=365}}</ref> that the work of C. Parker enables a complete knowledge of popular culture with an empathic and participative approach on the “culture of the poor”. His contribution to the sociology of religion, underscoring its cultural character, rich in creativity, has led to the reevaluation of lived religion,<ref>{{cite book|last1=McGuire|first1=Meredith|title=Lived Religion. Faith and Practice in Everyday Life|date=2008|publisher=Oxford University Press|location=New York|isbn=9780195368338|page=119}}</ref> i.e., to the noninstitutional character of religion. That is why his criticisms of the ecclesiocentric bias of the sociology of western religion have been the subject of relevant publications. According to Roberto Cipriani, Cristián Parker in his work “has analyzed with scientífic rigor the crossing of popular and official culture, revealing congruences and incongruences, points of contact and contrast through theoretical and empirical work made along a trip that has lasted 30 years, aimed at discovering what he calls the “other logic” of popular culture (...). On the other hand, an extensive analysis of the relation between religion and politics from a democratic perspective is not missing".<ref>{{cite book|last1=Cipriani|first1=Roberto|title=Manual de Sociología de la Religión|date=2011|publisher=Siglo Veintiuno Editores|location=Buenos Aires|isbn=978-987-629-194-1|page=365}}</ref> The work of C. Parker is consulted by specialists and those interested in Latin America’s sociocultural and religious evolution.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Llambías|first1=Jaime|title=América Latina : interrogantes y prespectivas|date=2013|publisher=York University Bookstore|location=Toronto|isbn=978-1-55014-583-0|pages=205–232}}</ref>
Professor Parker has contributed to the sociology of development, especially in his analysis of new ways of understanding the relation between culture and development. In particular, he has conducted research on the social representations of social actors challenged by the radical scientific and technological innovations in the context of unequal globalization and on the environmental crisis, climate change, and energy transition in South American societies.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Parker|first1=Cristian|last2=Letelier|first2=Mario|last3=Muñoz|first3=Juan|title=Elites, climate change and agency in a developing society: the Chilean case|journal=Environment, Development and Sustainability|date=20 March 2013|volume=15|issue=5|pages=1337–1363|doi=10.1007/s10668-013-9444-2}}</ref>
==Social commitment== During the time in which Chile was governed under the dictatorship of General [[Augusto Pinochet]], he became an active actor of a Catholic church and of the ecumenical efforts in defense of human rights and the return to democracy. In those days he became committed with the Church's base communities that fought inspired by the Liberation Theology. As the country turned to democracy, and after the [[Chilean national plebiscite, 1988]] and the election of [[Patricio Aylwin]] as president of the democratic Concertación, he oriented his life toward academic work. During this time he has contributed in key and strategic issues of the social sciences for the construction of democracy in Chile: development of indigenous people, overcoming poverty, social and political participation of youngsters, ethics and democracy, and the challenges of climate change and sustainable development.
==Works== The writings of C. Parker reach 172 works, including books, book chapters,and papers.
===Books (author and coauthur===
2012 Religión, Política y Cultura en América Latina: Nuevas Miradas. Instituto de Estudios Avanzados – (Editor), Santiago: ACSRM- IDEA. 390 p. {{ISBN|9789563031454}}
2010 Parker, C., Estenssoro, F. (Co-ed), El Desafío del Conocimiento para América Latina. Santiago: Explora CONICYT-USACH. 411 p. {{ISBN|9789568416225}}
2002 La pobreza desde la perspectiva del desarrollo humano: desafío para las políticas públicas en América Latina. (Autor) Tegucigalpa, Honduras: PNUD. 25 p. {{ISBN|999266567X}}
2000 Los jóvenes chilenos, cambios culturales; perspectivas para el siglo XXI, (Autor),Santiago: MIDEPLAN. 197 p. {{ISBN|9567463719}}
1998 Ética, Democracia y Desarrollo Humano, (Editor), Santiago: [[LOM Ediciones]], CERC-UAHC. 385 p. {{ISBN|9562821056}}
1998 Ética, Cultura y Desarrollo: Alternativa para el siglo XXI, (Autor), Tegucigalpa, Honduras: Subirana. 127 p.
1997 Religión y Postmodernidad, (Autor), Lima: Kairos. 120 p.
1996 Otra Lógica en América latina, Religión popular y modernización capitalista, (Autor), México and Santiago: Fondo de Cultura Económica. 407 p. {{ISBN|9567083088}}
1996 Popular Religion and Modernization in Latin America, (Autor), New York: Orbis Books, Maryknoll, 251 p.
1996 Religiäo Popular e Modernizaçao capitalista, (Autor), Petrópolis, Rio de Janeiro: Vozes. 349 p.
1992 Parker, C., Aman, K. (Co-ed.), Popular Culture in Chile, Boulder, San Francisco: Westview Press. 225 p.
1992 Parker, C., Salvat, P. (Co-ed.), Formación cívica y política de la juventud, Santiago: Ediciones Ornitorrinco. 163 p.
===Noteworthy scientific papers===
2015 “" Religion et transition énergétique: une étude en Amérique du Sud" Social Compass, Vol, 62, N°3, September, pp. 344–361. (See paper on line) http://scp.sagepub.com/content/62/3/344.short
2015 “Agua-energía-minería, consumo sustentable y gobernanza: visión de actores estratégicos sudamericanos”. En B. Hogenboom, M Baud, F de Castro, (editores) Gobernanza Ambiental en América Latina, Clacso - Engov: Buenos Aires (see paper on line)
2013 “Elites, Climate Change and Agency in a Developing Society: the Chilean Case”, Environment, Development and Sustainability, Vol 15, Nº5, pp. 1337–1363. ISI (See paper on line)
2008, “Mentalidad religiosa post-ilustrada: creencias y esoterismo en una sociedad en mutuación cultural”, en Aurelio Alonso (ed) América Latina y el Caribe. Territorios religiosos y desafíos para el diálogo, Buenos Aires, CLACSO, Consejo Latinoamericano de Ciencias Sociales (See paper on line)
2008, “Interculturality, Conflicts and Religion: Theoretical Perspectivas”, Social Compass, Vol. 55, No. 3, pp. 316–329. (See paper on line)
2006, “Magico-popular religion' in contemporary society: towards a post-western sociology of religión”, en James A. Beckford, and John Walliss (eds.) Theorising Religion Classical and Contemporary Debates, Hampshire (UK)/Burlington (USA), Ashgate, pp. 60–74.
2002,“Religion and the Awakening of Indigenous People in Latin America", Social Compass, Vol.1, Nº 49, pp. 67–81. (See paper on line)
1998, “Modern Popular Religión, A Complex Object of Study for Sociology”, International Sociology, Vol. 13, No. 2, 195-212. (See paper on line)

Interview in La Tercera newspaper] * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qQCfdPwwydU&feature=youtu.be Environmental Governance and Sustainable Development Conference, ECLAC (2015).] * [http://clacso.tv/c.php?id_video=443 Interview to C. Parker by CLACSO TV about Environmental Governace in Latin America (Spanish)] * [http://www.elmostrador.cl/opinion/2015/04/28/mercado-consumista-cortoplacismo-y-corrupcion/ “Ética, Democracia y Corrupción”. revision.comment: Qarqe'an was erroneously described as both "annual" and "biannual"--these references were both changed to the correct "semiannual"
revision.text:
[[File:Oman (124).jpg|thumbnail|An Omani family]] [[File:Kuwaititabla.jpg|thumb|right|200px|Tabla player at the 8th International [[Music Festival]] in Kuwait.]] There is a rich and ancient culture in [[Eastern Arabia]] ([[Arab states of the Persian Gulf]]). Eastern Arabia's culture has always been [[Seafaring|oriented towards the sea]].<ref name="an">{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=hsU798UPaeYC&pg=PA67&dq|title=Iranians in Bahrain and the United Arab Emirates|work=Eric Andrew McCoy|pages=67–68}}</ref> While being [[Arab culture|Arab]] at its core, it has been heavily influenced by the cultures of [[Persian culture|Persia]], [[South Asian culture|South Asia]] and [[Horn of Africa]], because of extensive [[trade]] links.
The semiannual tradition of [[Qarqe'an]] (قرقيعان) is deeply rooted in Gulf culture. The [[Arab cuisine of the Persian Gulf|cuisine of the region]] includes [[seafood]] (including [[mahyawa]]), [[harees]], [[khubz]] and [[biryani]]. Other cultural features of the region include [[Badgeer|windcatchers (Badgeer)]] (barajeel) and [[Dewaniya]].
==Overview== Cultures in the region include those of [[Culture of Bahrain|Bahrain]], [[Culture of Kuwait|Kuwait]], [[UAE]], Eastern Saudi Arabia ([[Qatif]] and [[Al-Hasa]]), [[Qatar]], [[Southern Iraq]] and [[Culture of Oman|Northern Oman]].
==Gargee'an== {{See also|Gargee'an}} Qarqe'an is an semiannual celebration, observed in Eastern Arabia, that takes place on the 15th night of [[Sha'ban]] and on the 15th night of [[Ramadan]]. Gerga'oon is marked with children dressing in traditional attire and going door-to-door to receive [[sweets]] from neighbours, whilst also singing traditional songs. The tradition has existed for hundreds of years and deeply rooted in Gulf culture.<ref name=BNA>{{cite news|title=القرقاعون من أهم الاحتفالات الرمضانية الشعبية في مملكة البحرين|url=http://www.bna.bh/portal/news/519354|accessdate=3 February 2013|newspaper=[[Bahrain News Agency]]|date=2 August 2012}}</ref>
Although the celebration of Qarqe'an shares superficial similarities with the [[Halloween]] custom of [[trick-or-treating]], practiced in some western countries, Qarqe'an has no connection with horror and no associated origin with Halloween.
==Music== A variety of music and dance forms are practised in the region, including [[Fijiri]], [[Fann At-Tanbura]], [[Sawt (music)|Sawt]], [[Khaliji (music)|contemporary Khaliji music]], [[Yowla]] and [[Liwa (music)|Liwa]].
;Musical instruments Traditional instruments include the [[Oud]], along with a variety of [[drum]]s and the ''[[manjur (instrument)|manjur]]''. The ''[[Tanbūra (lyre)|Tanbūra]]'' lyre is also used.
==Languages== A number of different dialects of Arabic are spoken in the region, including [[Gulf Arabic]] and [[Bahrani Arabic]]. The [[Kumzari dialect|Lurs language of Kumzari]] is also spoken by [[Omani people]] of [[Musandam Peninsula]]. Kumzari is the only Iranian language native to the Arab world.
==Cuisine== {{See also|Arab cuisine of the Persian Gulf}} The cuisine of the region includes [[Harees]],<ref>Charles Perry, "Cooking with the Caliphs", ''Saudi Aramco World'' '''57''':4 (July/August 2006) [http://www.saudiaramcoworld.com/issue/200604/cooking.with.the.caliphs.htm full text]</ref> '''[[seafood]]''' (including [[mahyawa]]), [[Biryani]] and [[Ghormeh sabzi|Sabzi]].
==Dress== The dress of the region includes long [[Thobe]] (also called Dishdasha) for men, [[Bisht (clothing)|Bisht]] and [[Ghutra]].
==Transport== Traditional transport in the region includes boats such as [[Dhow]]s and [[Abra (boat)|Abra]]s.
==Other cultural features== [[Image:WindTower.JPG|thumb|top|right|500px|A [[badgeer]] wind tower in [[Muharraq]], [[Bahrain]]]]
<!--This ragbag list really needs to be broken up into useful sections, i.e. completely rewritten.--> Other cultural features of the region include [[Qarqe'an]], [[Badgeer]] wind towers, [[Bukhoor]] and [[Dewaniya]].
==Institutions== Cultural institutions of the region include the television network [[Al Jazeera]],<ref>Zayani, 2007</ref> broadcast from Qatar, and competitor [[Al Arabiya]], broadcast from Saudi Arabia.
==References==
{{reflist}}
==Bibliography== *{{cite book | url=https://books.google.com/books?isbn=0415331358 | title=Transnational Connections and the Arab Gulf|year=2005 | editor=[[Madawi Al-Rasheed]]}} *{{cite book | url=https://books.google.com/books?isbn=0230618456| title=The Persian Gulf in History |year=2009 | editor=Lawrence G. Potter}} * "The Gulf's Ethnic Diversity: An Evolutionary History" in ''Security in the Persian Gulf: Origins, Obstacles and the Search for Consensus'', Edited by G. Sick and L. Potter, pp. 284. *{{cite book| url=http://www12.georgetown.edu/sfs/qatar/cirs/SectarianPoliticsintheGulfSummaryReport.pdf| title=Sectarian Politics in the Gulf| year=2014| editor=Lawrence G. Potter| deadurl=yes| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130424051325/http://www12.georgetown.edu/sfs/qatar/cirs/SectarianPoliticsintheGulfSummaryReport.pdf| archivedate=2013-04-24| df=}}
[[Category:Middle Eastern culture]] [[Category:Arab culture]] [[Category:Persian Gulf]]

revision.text:
{{infobox book | <!-- See [[Wikipedia:WikiProject Novels]] or [[Wikipedia:WikiProject Books]] --> | name = Death in the Desert | title_orig = | translator = | image = Death in the Desert Image.jpg | caption = Death in the Desert cover | author = [[Cathy Scott]] | illustrator = | cover_artist = | country = United States | language = English | series = | genre = [[True crime]], [[biography]] | publisher = [[AuthorHouse]] | release_date = 2012 (first edition published 2000) | media_type = Print ([[Paperback]]) | pages = 322 pp | isbn = 978-1588205322 | isbn_note = (2nd edition, paperback) | dewey= | congress= | oclc= | preceded_by = | followed_by = }}
'''''Death in the Desert: The Ted Binion Homicide Case''''' is a 2000 biographical and crime account by the American [[journalist]] and crime [[author]] [[Cathy Scott]], with a second edition in 2012. The book, which was the first of four released about the case,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2001/Feb-08-Thu-2001/living/15362184.html |title=New Book: Photo Opportunity |publisher=''Las Vegas Review-Journal'' |date=2001-01-08 |accessdate=12-11-12}}</ref> details the homicide investigation and ensuing trial and re-trial of [[Ted Binion]]’s live-in girlfriend Sandy Murphy and her lover Rick Tabish in connection with Binion's death.
==Storyline== The book is an in-depth look at the life and death of Lonnie Theodore "Ted" Binion, the 54-year-old heir to [[Binion's Horseshoe Casino]], who died from a drug overdose on September 17, 1998. The book seeks to resolve whether Binion was murdered by Murphy and Tabish or accidentally overdosed on drugs he had purchased in the days before his death. It includes historical photos of the Binion family from the archives of the Las Vegas News Bureau and [[University of Nevada, Las Vegas]]'s [[Lied Library]] "Special Collections."
The murder motive, the prosecution contended, was Binion's $50 million estate. In his will, he left Murphy $300,000 cash in addition to his $900,000 house and its contents, which included original paintings and a silver coin collection kept in a safe inside the house.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lasvegassun.com/news/1999/jul/07/court-papers-reveal-two-sides-of-tabish-murphy/ |title=Court papers reveal two sides of Tabish, Murphy |publisher=''Las Vegas Sun'' |date=July 7, 1999 |accessdate=2012-11-09}}</ref>
The author interviewed the defendants before and after the first trial and re-trial, which was dubbed Las Vegas's "trial of the century."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2004/Nov-24-Wed-2004/news/25339516.html |title=Binion Trial Verdict: Reversal of fortunes |publisher=''Las Vegas Review-Journal'' |date=November 24, 2004 |accessdate=October 21, 2012}}</ref>
==Film== {{Main|Death in the Desert (film)}} ''Death in the Desert'', a full-length film that completed shooting in Las Vegas in February 2014,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt3562852/|title=Death in the Desert (2015)|author=|date=12 October 2015|work=IMDb}}</ref> is based on the book of the same title<ref>[http://www.reviewjournal.com/columns-blogs/john-l-smith/kindest-cut-all-cancer-patients Kindest cut of all for cancer patients (scroll to end) | ''Las Vegas Review-Journal''<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> with the script by [[screenwriter]] [[John Steppling (playwright)|John Steppling]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/joanna-perryfolino/man-of-conviction_b_4886456.html|title=Man of Conviction: John Steppling -- Playwright, Screenwriter and Teacher|author=|date=|work=The Huffington Post}}</ref> Directed and produced by [[Josh Evans (film producer)|Josh Evans]], it stars [[Michael Madsen]] as Ted Binion (played as Ray), [[Shayla Beesley]] as Sandy Murphy (played as Kim)<ref>[http://www.reviewjournal.com/columns-blogs/norm-clarke/photographer-helped-madsen-meet-sinatra Photographer helped Madsen meet Sinatra | ''Las Vegas Review-Journal''<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> and [[Paz de la Huerta]] as Kim's friend Margo,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt3564838/?ref_=nm_flmg_act_1|title=Death in the Desert (2015)|author=|date=12 October 2015|work=IMDb}}</ref> with a musical score by record producer [[Chris Goss]] and performed by singer [[Roxy Saint]]. The film premiered at the Tucson Film Festival on October 9, 2015. Distribution was scheduled for 2016 by Osiris Entertainment.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://moviepilot.com/posts/2015/10/11/death-in-the-desert-rolls-up-new-trailer-3585543?lt_source=external,manual,manual|title=Death in the Desert rolls up new trailer|author=Jessica Harmon|date=11 October 2015|work=moviepilot.com}}</ref>
==Popular culture== In 2012, author [[R. Barri Flowers]] chose the chapter "Fat Herbie Blitzstein" from ''Death in the Desert'' for inclusion in the anthology ''[[Masters of True Crime]]'' released by [[Prometheus Books]] in July 2012.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://truecrimezine.com/masters-of-true-crime-book-review/ |title=Review of Masters of True Crime: Chilling Stories of Murder and the Macabre edited by R. Barri Flowers |publisher=''True Crime Zine'' |date=August 22, 2012 |accessdate=October 20, 2012}}</ref>
[[Investigation Discovery]]'s series ''[[On the Case with Paula Zahn]]'' covered the case in 2009, interviewed the author, and gave the episode the same title as the book.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1558060/ |title=Death in the Desert |publisher=Investigation Discovery |accessdate=October 20, 2012}}</ref>
In 2006, Scott appeared on [[Oxygen Network]]’s “Snapped” series "Women Who Kill" about defendant Murphy, which was the show's fourth season debut episode.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.crimeandinvestigation.co.uk/shows/snapped-women-who-kill/videos/snapeed-women-who-kill-sandy-murphy-trial.html |title=Women Who Kill: Sandy Murphy |publisher=Crime and Investigation Network |date=October 2004 |accessdate=October 21, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130302071803/http://www.crimeandinvestigation.co.uk/shows/snapped-women-who-kill/videos/snapeed-women-who-kill-sandy-murphy-trial.html |archivedate=March 2, 2013 |df= }}</ref>
In October 2004, Steve Bornfeld with the ''Las Vegas Sun'' wrote a musical spoof about the Binion case and included Scott as one of the play's three narrators.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lasvegasweekly.com/news/archive/2004/oct/07/binion-the-miniature-musical/ |title=Binion: The Miniature Musical |publisher=''Las Vegas Weekly'' |date=October 7, 2004 |accessdate=October 20, 2012}}</ref>
==Critical reception==
The book was reviewed by the ''Nevada Historical Society Quarterly'' in fall 2002.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://museums.nevadaculture.org/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=468%3A2002&catid=13%3Ahistorical-society-reno&Itemid=462|title=Book Review|publisher=''Nevada Historical Society Quarterly''|date=Fall 2002|volume=45, number 3|page=}}</ref>
In February 2001, the ''Las Vegas Mercury'' called the book "lively and informative." AmericanMafia.com in 2003 described ''Death in the Desert'' as "objective and not favoring either the prosecution or the defense."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.americanmafia.com/inside_vegas/3-3-03_Inside_Vegas.html |title=Bad Judgment |publisher=AmericanMafia.com |date=March 3, 2003 |accessdate=October 20, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130725040136/http://www.americanmafia.com/Inside_Vegas/3-3-03_Inside_Vegas.html |archivedate=July 25, 2013 |df= }}</ref>
The book is on display at [[University of Nevada, Las Vegas]]'s [[Lied Library]] Special Collections.<ref>http://webpac.library.unlv.edu/search~S1/?searchtype=.&searcharg=b2306377</ref>
''[[True Crime Zine]]'', which gave the second edition of the book a five-star review in January 2013, wrote, "Even if you’ve seen the television episodes on the case, you still want to read ''Death In The Desert'' because it’s a rollercoaster of a read. ... Just when you think it ends, it doesn’t. There’s so much more and a surprise ending."<ref>[http://truecrimezine.com/ted-binion-murder-book-cathy-scott/ Ted Binion book: Death in the Desert by Cathy Scott | ''True Crime Zine''<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
== References == {{Reflist|2}}
==External links== *[http://www.cathyscott.com/pdf/PR_Binion.pdf Publisher's news release] *[http://www.lasvegasweekly.com/news/2008/dec/31/courtroom-bookshelf/ “From courtroom to bookshelf,” ''Las Vegas Weekly''] *[https://www.amazon.com/Death-Desert-Binion-Homicide-Case/dp/1588205320/ref=sr_1_2?s=books&ie=UTF8&qid=1384108076&sr=1-2&keywords=death+in+the+desert ''Death in the Desert'' Amazon page]

revision.text:
The '''East African Court of Appeal''' ('''EACA''') was a court which served as the appellate court for the British colonies in eastern Africa and west Asia.
The court was established in 1902 as the '''Eastern African Court of Appeal''' and was the appellate court for [[British Kenya]], [[Uganda Protectorate]], and [[Nyasaland]]. Later, the court's name was changed to the East African Court of Appeal, and in the 1950s to the '''Court of Appeal for East Africa''' or the '''Court of Appeal for Eastern Africa'''. The court was based in Kenya.
Over time, the jurisdiction of the court grew to become the appellate court for the [[Sultanate of Zanzibar]], [[Tanganyika (territory)|Tanganyika]], [[British Somaliland]], [[Aden Protectorate]], [[Colony of Aden]], [[British Seychelles]], and [[Saint Helena]].
Decisions of the court could be appealed with leave to the [[Judicial Committee of the Privy Council]].
The court was retained by independent [[Kenya]], [[Tanzania]], and [[Uganda]] as the appellate court for the [[East African Community]]. When the Community was abolished in 1977, so too was the court.
==References== *Bonny Ibhawoh, ''Imperial Justice: Africans in Empire's Court'' (Oxford: Oxford University Press, 2013) {{ISBN|9780199664849}}
{{law-stub}}
[[Category:Defunct courts]] [[Category:1902 establishments in Africa]] [[Category:1902 establishments in the British Empire]] [[Category:1977 disestablishments]] [[Category:British Kenya]] [[Category:Uganda Protectorate]] [[Category:Nyasaland]] [[Category:Sultanate of Zanzibar]] [[Category:Aden Protectorate]] [[Category:Colony of Aden]] [[Category:British Seychelles]] [[Category:Saint Helena]] [[Category:Appellate courts]] [[Category:British Somaliland]]

The '''East StratCom Task Force''' is a part of the [[Public administration|administration]] of the [[European union|European Union]], focused on [[proactive]] communication of EU [[policy|policies]] and activities in the Eastern neighbourhood ([[Armenia]], [[Azerbaijan]], [[Belarus]], [[Georgia (country)|Georgia]], [[Moldova]] and [[Ukraine]])<ref name="theg">{{cite web|title=EU to counter Russian propaganda by promoting 'European values'|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/jun/25/eu-russia-propaganda-ukraine|publisher=[[The Guardian]]|accessdate=28 November 2015|date=25 June 2015}}</ref> and beyond<ref name="ap">{{cite web|author1=East StratCom Team|title=Action Plan on Strategic Communication|website=[[Eastern Partnership]] Civil Society Forum|accessdate=28 November 2015|ref=Ref. Ares(2015)2608242 - 22/06/2015|pages=5| url=http://eap-csf.eu/assets/files/Action%20PLan.pdf |format=pdf}}</ref> ([[Russia]] itself).<ref name="theg" /> The Team was created as a conclusion of the [[European Council]] meeting on 19 and 20 March 2015, stressing the need to challenge the ongoing [[disinformation]] campaigns by [[Russia]].“<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eesc.europa.eu/resources/docs/european-council-conclusions-19-20-march-2015-en.pdf|title=European Council meeting (19 and 20 March 2015) - Conclusions|first=|date=2015-03-20|website=|location=Brussels|at=Paragraph 13|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|author1=European Council|accessdate=28 November 2015}}</ref>
== Mission and objectives == The East Stratcom Team is intended to develop dedicated communication material on priority issues, where EU [[strategic communication]] needs to be improved or the EU is subject to [[disinformation]] campaigns. Such products will be put at the disposal of the EU's political leadership, press services, EU [[delegation]]s and EU Member States and are intended for the widest possible public audience.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://eeas.europa.eu/headquarters/headquarters-Homepage/2116/questions-and-answers-about-east-stratcom-task-force_en|title=Questions and Answers about the East StratCom Task Force - EEAS - European External Action Service - European Commission|website=EEAS - European External Action Service|language=en|access-date=2018-03-19}}</ref> The Team is designated to develop communication campaigns, targeting key [[audience]]s and focused on specific issues of relevance to those audiences, including local issues. The actions of the East Stratcom Team are built on existing work and coherent with wider EU communication efforts, including activities of the EU institutions and EU Member States.<ref name="ap" />
== Key Task Force products == The team's positive communications products are mainly focused on the countries of the Eastern Neighbourhood and produced in the local languages of those countries. They are distributed via social media channels of the EU Delegations in the region, and are also carried on television and via other media and public events.<ref name="Q & A">{{cite web|title=Questions and Answers about the East StratCom Task Force|url=https://eeas.europa.eu/headquarters/headquarters-Homepage/2116/questions-and-answers-about-east-stratcom-task-force_en|publisher=EEAS - European External Action Service|language=en}} Material has been copied from this source. Reuse is authorised, provided the source is acknowledged.</ref> In addition, the Task Force, in cooperation with the European Commission, led the EU's six month Eastern Partnership communications campaign culminating in the November 2017 Eastern Partnership Summit in Brussels.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://eeas.europa.eu/headquarters/headquarters-homepage/36233/eastern-partnership-summit-24112017_en|title=Eastern Partnership summit, 24/11/2017 - EEAS - European External Action Service - European Commission|website=EEAS - European External Action Service|language=en|access-date=2018-03-19}}</ref>
The team's main product to raise awareness of disinformation is the weekly Disinformation Review (in English and Russian languages). This can provide valuable data for analysts, journalists and officials dealing with this issue. The Disinformation Review also brings the latest news and analyses of pro-Kremlin disinformation.<ref name="Q & A"/> Launched in November 2015, the Disinformation Review has been described as "the best weekly disinformation bulletin anywhere in the West"<ref>{{Citation|last=|title=Lecture by Edward Lucas|date=2016-07-17|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=sx_cqNR3bJA%7Clanguage=en%7Caccessdate=2018-03-19|accessdate=2018-04-04}}</ref>. The full record of the Task Force's work on disinformation is available on its website [https://euvsdisinfo.eu/ EUvsDisinfo.eu] (in [https://euvsdisinfo.eu/news/ English], [https://euvsdisinfo.eu/ru/ Russian] and [https://euvsdisinfo.eu/de/ German] languages). The team also runs the European External Action Service's [https://eeas.europa.eu/ru/eu-information-russian_ru Russian language website]. It is also possible to follow the team on Twitter and Facebook. This communicates primarily about the EU's foreign policy by publishing information about EU activities, as well as EU statements and press releases with relevance to the Eastern Neighbourhood in particular.<ref name="Q & A"/>
== Reception and criticism == EU Member State Governments have strongly supported the Task Force since its inception and provide the majority of its staff.
The European Parliament has consistently supported the Task Force and called for adequate staffing and resourcing. An EP preparatory action for 2018 – "StratCom Plus" - has allocated €1.1m for the team to focus on how to counter disinformation on the EU more systematically.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2017/nov/25/eu-anti-propaganda-unit-gets-1m-a-year-to-counter-russian-fake-news|title=EU anti-propaganda unit gets €1m a year to counter Russian fake news|last=Rankin|first=Jennifer|date=2017-11-25|website=the Guardian|language=en|access-date=2018-03-19}}</ref> * [[Pavel Telička|Pavel Telicka]], Vice-President of the European Parliament: "I place great value in the fact that Europe has experts who address Russia's ongoing disinformation campaigns (…). The quality and the substance of their work is outstanding. Their work is valuable as it indicated the alarming nature of our European security".<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.telicka.eu/cs/articles/detail/647|title=Pavel Telička píše F. Mogheriniové. Oceňuje práci East StratCom Task Force|last=<hello@unchained.studio|first=UNCHAINED.studio|website=www.telicka.eu|language=cs|access-date=2018-03-19}}</ref> * Keir Giles from [[Chatham House]] about East StratCom Task Force: "a critically important capability, ESTF has quite a high credit among experts".<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://ec.europa.eu/transparency/regexpert/index.cfm?do=groupDetail.groupDetail&groupID=3567&news=1|title=Register of Commission expert groups and other similar entities|website=ec.europa.eu|access-date=2018-03-19}}</ref> * European Security Union Commissioner [[Julian King (diplomat)|Julian King]] noted that East Stratcom Task Force "gathered more than 3,500 examples of pro-Kremlin disinformation contradicting publicly available facts repeated on many languages on many occasions”;<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.neweurope.eu/article/meps-call-boosting-eu-resilience-russian-propaganda/|title=MEPs call for boosting EU resilience to Russian propaganda|date=2018-01-18|work=New Europe|access-date=2018-03-19|language=en-US}}</ref> "It also launched a Russian language service from Brussels, providing updates and fact-based background information about the Union for RU language journalists. The aim is to increase visibility and more accurate representation of EU policies in the Russian language media. It produces a weekly Disinformation review. Their Twitter account ensures that the Task Force's products reach up to 2 million people per month, in addition to their regular briefings. This work is very important".<ref name="europarl.europa.eu">{{Cite web|url=http://www.europarl.europa.eu/ep-live/en/plenary/video?debate=1516197858767|title=Plenary video: Russia - the influence of propaganda on EU countries {{!}} Multimedia centre {{!}} European Parliament|website=Multimedia centre {{!}} European Parliament|language=en|access-date=2018-03-19}}</ref> * [[Rebecca Harms]], Member of the European Parliament (MEP) from Germany and member of the Greens group: "It's important to have this Stratcom, but its interaction with national bodies is not strong enough".<ref name="europarl.europa.eu"/> * Former Danish Foreign Minister Uffe Ellemann-Jensen said that: "They provide an excellent instrument. We would of course not be able to do it in other ways".<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://pov.international/truslen-fra-ost-eller-hvordan-jeg-holdt-op-med-bekymre-mig-og-laerte-elske-sandheden/|title=Truslen fra øst eller: Hvordan jeg holdt op med at bekymre mig og lærte at elske sandheden - POV|last=Skovgaard|first=Morten|date=2017-01-30|work=POV|access-date=2018-03-19|language=da-DK}}</ref> * Former Czech Prime Minister [[Bohuslav Sobotka]]: "This team is capable of generating quality results".<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.vlada.cz/cz/media-centrum/aktualne/premier-bohuslav-sobotka-se-zucastnil-stratcom-summitu-2017-156424/|title=Premiér Bohuslav Sobotka se zúčastnil Stratcom Summitu 2017|access-date=2018-03-19|language=cs}}</ref> * Edward Lucas, vice president at [[Center for European Policy Analysis|CEPA]], said that the East StratCom's Disinformation Review is "the best weekly bulletin on Russian propaganda in the West" next after Ukrainian similar project, StopFake, which he considers to be "the gold standard".<ref name="Lecture by Edward Lucas">{{Citation|title=Lecture by Edward Lucas|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=sx_cqNR3bJA|language=en|accessdate=2018-03-19}}</ref> * According to The New York Times, East Stratcom serves as "Europe’s front line against this onslaught of fake news".<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/02/20/world/europe/europe-combats-a-new-foe-of-political-stability-fake-news.html|title=Europe Combats a New Foe of Political Stability: Fake News|last=Scott|first=Mark|date=2017-02-20|work=The New York Times|access-date=2018-03-19|last2=Eddy|first2=Melissa|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}}</ref> * Canadian [[Maclean's|Maclean's Magazine]]: "As for who first noticed that Moscow was gunning for Freeland, that’s something that has yet to show up in any banner Canadian headlines. It was the European Union’s East StratCom Task Force, a unit of the External Action Service (the EU’s foreign ministry and diplomatic branch). The Task Force was set up in March 2015 as a kind of early warning system to detect incoming Kremlin disinformation campaigns".<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.macleans.ca/politics/how-russias-attack-on-freeland-got-traction-in-canada/|title=How Russia's attack on Freeland got traction in Canada - Macleans.ca|date=2017-03-14|work=Macleans.ca|access-date=2018-03-19|language=en-US}}</ref> * East StratCom Task Force in EU Observer: "Eight member states have urged the EU's foreign service to significantly expand its work on countering Russian propaganda. They said in a letter to EU foreign affairs chief Federica Mogherini that "in the face of unabated third party disinformation campaigns … we see an urgent need to further enhance the EU's StratCom capabilities (…) East StratCom circulates online notes that debunk Russian disinformation and has attracted 30,000 followers to its Twitter account. It also promotes positive coverage of the EU in former Soviet states".<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://euobserver.com/foreign/139573|title=Mogherini urged to do more on Russian propaganda|access-date=2018-03-19|language=en}}</ref> More in [[EU Observer]]: "Its Disinformation Review, a weekly newsletter, and its daily tweets and infographics, should be in the laptops and phones of all MEPs and senior EU officials".<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://euobserver.com/opinion/136198|title=[Opinion] No joke: Russian propaganda poses EU threat|access-date=2018-03-19|language=en}}</ref> * Lawfare Blog about the team: "The task force has made some meaningful contributions to the efforts to counter disinformation warfare. Over the course of its operation, East StratCom has identified over 3,500 disinformation cases (…) These statistics highlight the global nature of the problem, and the benefit of having a body working on disinformation beyond a single country’s borders. East StratCom’s supranational view also allows it to provide valuable insights into the broader strategy and goals of pro-Kremlin disinformation operations because it can see them as a cohesive whole, rather than isolated incidents in individual countries.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://lawfareblog.com/european-union-steps-its-fight-against-fake-news|title=The European Union Steps Up its Fight Against Fake News|date=2017-11-14|work=Lawfare|access-date=2018-03-19|language=en}}</ref>
=== Criticism === An article published October 2016 on Kommunikations Forum analyses the sources East StratCom use for debunking alleged disinformation. It criticizes the top three sites, Ukrainian StopFake, EU and NATO, for not being objective credible sources in this regard.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.kommunikationsforum.dk/artikler/Hvad-er-EU-s-anti-propaganda-task-forces-ideologiske-fundament|title=EU tilbageviser propaganda med objektiv sandhed|last=|first=|date=26 October 2016|work=Kommunikations Forum|access-date=28 February 2018|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.academia.edu/29394520/Analysis_of_East_StratCom_sources_for_debunking_pro-Kremlin_misinformation|title=Analysis of East StratCom sources for debunking pro-Kremlin misinformation|last=Jesper|first=Larsen|date=24 October 2016|website=Academia|access-date=28 February 2018}}</ref>
An opinion piece written by Danish commentator, Iben Thranholm, published on Russia Insider October 2015, were listed by East StratCom as pro-Kremlin disinformation. Member of the Danish Parliament, Marie Krarup, upon discovery raised the issue in January 2017, demanding Foreign Minister, Anders Samuelsen, to take action and stop ‘black listing’ of opinions, which he declined as the listing in his view was correctly labeled 'disinformation in support for Russia'.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.altinget.dk/eu/artikel/udenrigsminister-dansk-debattoer-er-korrekt-opfoert-paa-propaganda-liste|title=Minister: Dansk debattør er korrekt opført på propaganda-liste|last=|first=|date=12 January 2017|website=Altinget|access-date=28 February 2018}}</ref> In response 28 commentators wrote a joint critique stressing their concern that ‘anybody with a critical view on mass immigration could end up in the black book of EU’.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.b.dk/kommentarer/28-kommentatorer-udenrigsministeren-stoetter-sortlistning-af-iben-thranholm|title=28 kommentatorer: Udenrigsministeren støtter sortlistning af Iben Thranholm|last=|first=|date=16 January 2017|website=Berlingske Tidende|access-date=28 February 2018}}</ref>
An article published October 2016 on Folkets Avis, lists several instances, where East StratCom has labelled critique of non Western immigration to EU as pro-Kremlin disinformation, regardless that neither the media or the content has any relation to Russia.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.folkets.dk/c/russisk-propaganda-EU-islamkritik|title=EU's East Stratcom: Islamkritik er russisk propaganda|last=|first=|date=6 October 2016|website=Folkets Avis|access-date=28 February 2018}}</ref>
Research conducted by investigative journalists at Danish newspaper, Politiken, showed that East StratCom along with Western media falsely blamed separatists, not government forces, in Eastern Ukraine for initiating an offensive in the area of Avdiivka in January 2017. Sources used by East StratCom included [[Inform Napalm|InformNapalm]] which the article shows has ties to Ukrainian death list, [[Myrotvorets]] (Peacemaker) that lists people including journalists as 'traitors' for expressing certain opinions or visiting separatist controlled areas in Eastern Ukraine.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://politiken.dk/udland/art5851073/EU-er-fanget-i-propaganda-krigens-t%C3%A5ger|title=EU er fanget i propaganda-krigens tåger|last=|first=|date=27 February 2017|work=Politiken|access-date=28 February 2018|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref>
Upon discovery of being listed for publishing pro-Kremlin disinformation, three Dutch major media organisations has sued the EU for libel.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://kvdl.com/wp-content/uploads/sites/3/2018/02/Writ-of-summons-GS-TPO-Gelderlander-EU-Disinfo.pdf|title=Court subpoena in English|last=|first=|date=19 February 2018|website=Kenny Van der Laan lawfirm|access-date=28 February 2018}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.dutchnews.nl/news/archives/2018/02/dutch-media-outlets-take-eu-to-court-over-disinformation-claims/|title=Dutch media outlets take EU to court over disinformation claims|last=|first=|date=21 February 2018|work=Dutch News|access-date=28 February 2018|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.poynter.org/news/three-publications-are-suing-eu-over-fake-news-allegations|title=Three publications are suing the EU over fake news allegations|last=|first=|date=28 February 2018|work=Poynter|access-date=1 March 2018|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref> On 6 March 2018, a majority of 109 votes to 41 of the Dutch Parliament voted to close EUvsDisinfo.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.tweedekamer.nl/kamerstukken/moties/detail?id=2018Z03708&did=2018D18080|title=Gewijzigde motie van de leden Kwint en Yesilgöz-Zegerius over het opheffen van EU versus Disinfo (t.v.v. 21501-34-286) (Proposal to close East StratCom)|last=|first=|date=6 March 2018|website=Tweede Kamer|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=12 March 2018}}</ref> On 8 March 2018, East StratCom announced they had deleted the listings of Dutch media in their database "following a detailed review".<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://euvsdisinfo.eu/removal-of-three-cases-further-to-complaints-by-dutch-media/|title=Removal of three cases further to complaints by Dutch media|last=|first=|date=8 March 2018|website=EU vs Disinformation|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=12 March 2018}}</ref> On 9 March 2018, Dutch Minister of the Interior, who had previously<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.rd.nl/vandaag/politiek/kabinet-trotseert-kamer-over-nepnieuwswaakhond-1.1471637|title=Kabinet trotseert Kamer over nepnieuwswaakhond (Cabinet defies Chamber about fake news watchdog)|last=|first=|date=6 March 2018|work=Reformatorisch Dagblad|access-date=12 March 2018|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref> opposed closing EUvsDisinfo, said that the government would make a case for closing it in the European Union.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://nos.nl/artikel/2221353-ook-ollongren-wil-nu-af-van-europese-waakhond-nepnieuws.html|title=Ook Ollongren wil nu af van Europese waakhond nepnieuws (Ollongren now also wants to get rid of European watchdog fake news)|last=|first=|date=10 March 2018|work=NOS|access-date=12 March 2018|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://politiek.tpo.nl/2018/03/09/ollongren-nu-toch-anti-nepnieuwsbureau/|title=Minister Kajsa Ollongren nu toch tegen anti-nepnieuwsbureau (Minister Kajsa Ollongren now against anti-fake news agency)|last=|first=|date=9 March 2018|work=The Post Online (TPO)|access-date=12 March 2018|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref> On 13 March 2018 the three Dutch media withdrew their case.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://nos.nl/artikel/2222185-media-trekken-kort-geding-tegen-eu-om-nepnieuws-in.html|title=Media trekken kort geding tegen EU om nepnieuws in|access-date=2018-03-19|language=nl}}</ref>

The United States [[Federal Trade Commission | Federal Trade Commission's]] '''fair information practice principles''' (FIPPs) are guidelines that represent widely accepted concepts concerning fair information practice in an electronic marketplace.<ref name=FTCFIPPS>Federal Trade Commission, [http://www.ftc.gov/reports/privacy3/fairinfo.shtm Fair Information Practice Principles.] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090331134113/http://www.ftc.gov/reports/privacy3/fairinfo.shtm |date=March 31, 2009 }}</ref>
== Introduction ==
FTC Fair Information Practice Principles are the result of the Commission's inquiry into the way in which online entities collect and use personal information and safeguards to assure that practice is fair and provides adequate [[information privacy]] protection. The FTC has been studying online privacy issues since 1995, and in its 1998 report,<ref>Federal Trade Commission, ''[https://www.ftc.gov/sites/default/files/documents/reports/privacy-online-report-congress/priv-23a.pdf Privacy Online: A Report to Congress]'' (June 1998).</ref> the Commission described the widely accepted Fair Information Practice Principles of ''Notice, Choice, Access, and Security''.<ref name=FTCFIPPS/> The Commission also identified ''Enforcement'', the use of a reliable mechanism to provide sanctions for noncompliance as a critical component of any governmental or self-regulatory program to protect online privacy.<ref name=FTCFIPPS/>
== History and development ==
Fair Information Practice was initially proposed and named<ref>US Secretary's Advisory Committee on Automated Personal Data Systems, ''[http://aspe.hhs.gov/DATACNCL/1973privacy/c4.htm Records, Computers and the Rights of Citizens]'', Chapter IV: Recommended Safeguards for Administrative Personal Data Systems (1973).</ref> by the ''US Secretary's Advisory Committee on Automated Personal Data Systems'' in a 1973 report, ''Records, Computers and the Rights of Citizens'',<ref>US Secretary's Advisory Committee on Automated Personal Data Systems, ''[http://aspe.hhs.gov/DATACNCL/1973privacy/tocprefacemembers.htm Records, Computers and the Rights of Citizens]'' (1973).</ref> issued in response to the growing use of automated data systems containing information about individuals. The central contribution of the Advisory Committee was the development of a code of fair information practice for automated personal data systems. The Privacy Protection Study Commission also may have contributed to the development of FIPs principles in its 1977 report, ''Personal Privacy in an Information Society''.<ref>Privacy Protection Study Commission, ''[http://epic.org/privacy/ppsc1977report/ Personal Privacy in an Information Society]'' (July 1977).</ref>
As privacy laws spread to other countries in Europe, international institutions took up privacy with a focus on the international implications of privacy regulation. In 1980, the [[Council of Europe]] adopted a [[Convention for the Protection of Individuals with regard to Automatic Processing of Personal Data|Convention for the Protection of Individuals with Regard to Automatic Processing of Personal Data]].<ref>Council of Europe,''[http://conventions.coe.int/Treaty/EN/Treaties/HTML/108.htm Convention for the Protection of Individuals with Regard to Automatic Processing of Personal Data]'' (Jan. 28, 1981).</ref> At the same time, the [[Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development|Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD)]] proposed similar privacy guidelines in the OECD Guidelines on the Protection of Privacy and Transborder Flows of Personal Data.<ref>Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD), ''[http://www.oecd.org/document/18/0,3343,en_2649_34255_1815186_1_1_1_1,00.html OECD Guidelines on the Protection of Privacy and Transborder Flows of Personal Data]'' (Sep. 23, 1980).</ref> The OECD Guidelines, [[Council of Europe]] Convention, and [[European Union]] [[Data Protection Directive]]<ref>European Union Data Protection Directive, Directive 95/46/EC http://docs.cpuc.ca.gov/published/proceedings/R0812009.htm</ref> relied on FIPs as core principles. All three organizations revised and extended the original U.S. statement of FIPs, with the OECD Privacy Guidelines being the version most often cited in subsequent years.<ref name=gellman>Robert Gellman, ''[https://papers.ssrn.com/sol3/papers.cfm?abstract_id=2950752 Fair Information Practices: A Basic History]'' (Apr. 10, 2017).</ref>
== Principles== The core principles of privacy addressed by these principles are:
'''1. Notice/Awareness<ref name=FIPNotice>Federal Trade Commission, [http://www.ftc.gov/reports/privacy3/fairinfo.shtm#Notice/Awareness Fair Information Practice Principles (FIPs), 1. Notice/Awareness.] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100309105100/http://www.ftc.gov/reports/privacy3/fairinfo.shtm#Notice/Awareness |date=March 9, 2010 }}</ref>''' Consumers should be given notice of an entity's information practices before any personal information is collected from them.<ref name=FIPNotice/> This requires that companies explicitly notify some or all of the following: *identification of the entity collecting the data; *identification of the uses to which the data will be put; *identification of any potential recipients of the data; *the nature of the data collected and the means by which it is collected; *whether the provision of the requested data is voluntary or required; *the steps taken by the data collector to ensure the confidentiality, integrity and quality of the data.<ref name=FIPNotice/>
'''2. Choice/Consent<ref name=FIPConsent>Federal Trade Commission, [http://www.ftc.gov/reports/privacy3/fairinfo.shtm#Choice/Consent Fair Information Practice Principles (FIPs), 2. Choice/Consent.] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100309105100/http://www.ftc.gov/reports/privacy3/fairinfo.shtm#Choice/Consent |date=March 9, 2010 }}</ref>''' Choice and consent in an on-line information-gathering sense means giving consumers options to control how their data is used. Specifically, choice relates to secondary uses of information beyond the immediate needs of the information collector to complete the consumer's transaction. The two typical types of choice models are 'opt-in' or 'opt-out.' The 'opt-in' method requires that consumers affirmatively give permission for their information to be used for other purposes. Without the consumer taking these affirmative steps in an 'opt-in' system, the information gatherer assumes that it cannot use the information for any other purpose. The 'opt-out' method requires consumers to affirmatively decline permission for other uses. Without the consumer taking these affirmative steps in an 'opt-out' system, the information gatherer assumes that it ''can'' use the consumer's information for other purposes. Each of these systems can be designed to allow an individual consumer to tailor the information gatherer's use of the information to fit their preferences by checking boxes to grant or deny permission for specific purposes rather than using a simple "all or nothing" method.<ref name=FIPConsent/>
'''2-1. Problems with Choice/Consent <ref name=jhhwang7>Tavani, H.T. & Bottis M. (2010, June). The consent process in medical research involving DNA databanks: some ethical implications and challenges. ACM SIGCAS Computers and Society, 40(2), 11-21. {{doi|10.1145/1839994.1839996}}</ref>''' Consumers do not have a fair say in the consent process. For example, customers provide their health information such as their social insurance number or health card number while making on-line an appointment for a dental check-up. Customers are commonly asked to sign an agreement stating that a ‘third-party may have an access to the information you provide under certain conditions.’ The certain conditions are rarely specified in any part of the agreement. Later on, the third-party may share the information with their subsidiary institutions. Thus, access to customers’ personal information is beyond their control.<ref name=jhhwang7/>
'''3. Access/Participation<ref name=FIPAccess>Federal Trade Commission, [http://www.ftc.gov/reports/privacy3/fairinfo.shtm#Access/Participation Fair Information Practice Principles (FIPs), 3. Access/Participation.] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100309105100/http://www.ftc.gov/reports/privacy3/fairinfo.shtm#Access/Participation |date=March 9, 2010 }}</ref>''' Access as defined in the Fair Information Practice Principles includes not only a consumer's ability to view the data collected, but also to verify and contest its accuracy. This access must be inexpensive and timely in order to be useful to the consumer.<ref name=FIPAccess/>
'''4. Integrity/Security<ref name=FIPSecurity>Federal Trade Commission, [http://www.ftc.gov/reports/privacy3/fairinfo.shtm#Integrity/Security Fair Information Practice Principles (FIPs), 4. Integrity/Security.] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100309105100/http://www.ftc.gov/reports/privacy3/fairinfo.shtm#Integrity/Security |date=March 9, 2010 }}</ref>''' Information collectors should ensure that the data they collect is accurate and secure. They can improve the integrity of data by cross-referencing it with only reputable databases and by providing access for the consumer to verify it. Information collectors can keep their data secure by protecting against both internal and external security threats. They can limit access within their company to only necessary employees to protect against internal threats, and they can use encryption and other computer-based security systems to stop outside threats.<ref name=FIPSecurity/>
'''5. Enforcement/Redress<ref name=FIPEnforcement>Federal Trade Commission, [http://www.ftc.gov/reports/privacy3/fairinfo.shtm#Enforcement/Redress Fair Information Practice Principles (FIPs), 5. Enforcement/Redress.] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100309105100/http://www.ftc.gov/reports/privacy3/fairinfo.shtm#Enforcement/Redress |date=March 9, 2010 }}</ref>''' In order to ensure that companies follow the Fair Information Practice Principles, there must be enforcement measures. The FTC identified three types of enforcement measures: self-regulation by the information collectors or an appointed regulatory body; private remedies that give civil causes of action for individuals whose information has been misused to sue violators; and government enforcement that can include civil and criminal penalties levied by the government.<ref name=FIPEnforcement/>
== Enforcing the principles==
Currently the FTC version of the Fair Information Principles are only recommendations for maintaining privacy-friendly, consumer-oriented data collection practices, and are not enforceable by law. The enforcement of and adherence to these principles is principally performed through self-regulation. The FTC has, however, undertaken efforts to evaluate industry self-regulation practices,<ref name =industryguidelines>FTC Industry Association Guidelines http://www.ftc.gov/reports/privacy3/industry.shtm#Industry%20Association%20Guidelines%20A</ref> provides guidance for industry in developing information practices,<ref name=infopractices>Protecting Personal Information: A Guide for Business http://www.ftc.gov/infosecurity/</ref> and uses its authority under the FTC Act to enforce promises made by corporations in their privacy policies.<ref name=title5privacy>Enforcing Privacy Promises: Section 5 of the FTC Act http://www.ftc.gov/privacy/privacyinitiatives/promises.html</ref>
Since self-regulatory initiatives fall short of ideal implementation of the principles (the 2000 FTC Report noted, for example, that self-regulatory initiatives lacked meaningful monitoring and enforcement policies and practices), the Commission recommends that the [[United States Congress]] enact legislation that, in conjunction with continuing self-regulatory programs, will ensure adequate protection of consumer privacy online.<ref name=2000report>FTC 2000 Privacy Report http://www.ftc.gov/reports/privacy2000/privacy2000.pdf</ref> "The legislation recommended by the Commission would set forth a basic level of privacy protection for consumer-oriented commercial Web sites" and "would establish basic standards of practice for the collection of information online...consumer-oriented commercial Web sites that collect personal identifying information from or about consumers online... would be required to comply with the four widely-accepted fair information practices."<ref name=gellman></ref>
The principles, however, form the basis of many individual laws at the both federal and state levels—called the "sectoral approach." Examples are the [[Fair Credit Reporting Act]], the [[Right to Financial Privacy Act]], the [[Electronic Communications Privacy Act]], the [[Video Privacy Protection Act]] (VPPA), and the [[Cable Television Protection and Competition Act]].<ref name=DHS>Department of Homeland Security, Privacy Policy Guidance Memorandum (2008) (Memorandum Number 2008-1), https://www.dhs.gov/xlibrary/assets/privacy/privacy_policyguide_2008-01.pdf</ref> Additionally, the principles continue to serve as a model for privacy protections in newly developing areas, such as in designing Smart Grid programs.<ref>Electronic Frontier Foundation and Center for Democracy and Technology Joint Filing with the California Public Utilities Commission regarding California's Smart Grid Program. http://www.cpuc.ca.gov/EFILE/CM/114696.pdf; https://www.eff.org/deeplinks/2010/03/new-smart-meters-energy-use-put-privacy-risk</ref>
==Other proposals regarding 'fair information'==
The [[Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development]] (OECD) and [[European Union]], among others, have adopted more comprehensive approaches to fair information practices. The OECD principles provide added protections via the ''Individual Participation principle'' where specific requirements are made for access and modification of personally collected information by the individual and the ''Accountability principle'' (a data controller should be accountable for complying with measures which give effect to the principles stated above).<ref>Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD), OECD Guidelines on the Protection of Privacy and Transborder Flows of Personal Data (Sep. 23, 1980).http://www.oecd.org/document/18/0,3343,en_2649_34255_1815186_1_1_1_1,00.html</ref><ref>Pam Dixon, ''[http://www.worldprivacyforum.org/fairinformationpractices.html A Brief Introduction to Fair Information Practices]'' World Privacy Forum (June 5, 2006).</ref>
The [[European Union]] [[Data Protection Directive]] is another model for comprehensive privacy protections.<ref name=datadirective>Directive 95/46/EC http://eur-lex.europa.eu/LexUriServ/LexUriServ.do?uri=CELEX:31995L0046:EN:HTML</ref><ref>[[Spiros Simitis]], From the Market to the Polis: The EU Directive on the Protection of Personal Data, 80 Iowa L. Rev. 445 (1995).</ref>
== Criticism of the FTC principles==
The FIPPs are criticized by some scholars for being less comprehensive in scope than privacy regimes in other countries, in particular in the European Union and other OECD countries. Additionally, the FTC's formulation of the principles has been criticized in comparison to those issued by other agencies. The [https://web.archive.org/web/20090205180646/http://ftc.gov/reports/privacy3/fairinfo.shtm FTC's 2000 version of FIPs] is shorter and less complete than the privacy protection principles issued by the Privacy Office of the [[Department of Homeland Security]] in 2008, which include eight principles closely aligned with the OECD principles.<ref name=DHS/>
Some in the privacy community criticize the FIPPs for being too weak, allowing too many exemptions, failing to require a privacy agency, failing to account for the weaknesses of self-regulation, and not keeping pace with information technology. {{Citation needed|date=June 2014}} Many privacy experts have called for omnibus privacy protection legislation in the US<ref>Paul M. Schwartz, Privacy and Democracy in Cyberspace, 52 Vand. L. Rev. 1609 (1999); Joel R. Reidenberg, Restoring Americans' Privacy in Electronic Commerce, 14 Berkeley Tech. L. J. 771 (1999).</ref> in lieu of the current blend of self-regulation and selective codification in certain sectors.<ref>Examples are the [[Fair Credit Reporting Act]], the [[Right to Financial Privacy Act]], the [[Electronic Communications Privacy Act]], and the [[Video Privacy Protection Act]]. Beth Givens, ''[http://www.privacyrights.org/ar/fairinfo.htm A Review of the Fair Information Principles : The Foundation of Privacy Public Policy]'' (posted 1997, updated 2004).</ref>
Critics from a business perspective often prefer to limit FIPs to reduced elements of notice, consent, and accountability. They complain that other elements are unworkable, expensive, or inconsistent with openness or free speech principles.<ref name=gellman></ref>

{{use mdy dates|date=August 2015}} {{Infobox book <!-- See [[Wikipedia:WikiProject Novels]] or [[Wikipedia:WikiProject Books]] --> | name = Grantville Gazette II | author = [[Eric Flint]], ''et al.'' | image = Grantville Gazette IIb-eMag cover - 1011250007.jpg <!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:Grantville Gazette-IIa-cover-1416520511.jpg|158px|Grantville Gazette II hardcover cover.|{{Deletable image-caption|1=Wednesday, 29 July 2009|date=March 2012}}]] --> | caption = ''Grantville Gazette II'' cover as a serialized [[eMagazine]]<!--The cover art by [[Thomas Kidd (illustrator)|Thomas Kidd]] is adapted from [[Rembrandt]]'s famous ''[[Night Watch (painting)|Night Watch]]'' (1642).--> | cover_artist = [[Thomas Kidd (illustrator)|Thomas Kidd]] | country = United States | language = English | series = [[1632 series]] | genre = [[Science fiction]] | published = March 7, 2006 [[Baen Books]] | media_type = [[E-book]] & Print ([[Hardback]]) | pages = 336 pages | isbn = 978-1-4165-2051-1 | preceded_by = [[Grantville Gazette I]] | followed_by = [[Grantville Gazette III]] }} {{Main article|1632 series|The Grantville Gazettes}}
'''''Grantville Gazette II''''' is the third collaborative anthology published in print set in the [[1632-verse]] [[shared universe]] in what is best regarded as a canonical sub-series of the popular [[alternate history]] that began with the February 2000 publication of the hardcover novel [[1632 (novel)|1632]] by author-historian [[Eric Flint]]. Baen Books and Flint decline the distinction, counting this book as the sixth published work. Overall it is also the third anthology in printed publication in the atypical series which consists of a mish-mash of main novels and anthologies produced under popular demand after publication of the initial novel which was written as a stand-alone work.
==Plot Synopses==
==="Steps in the Dance"=== : by [[Eric Flint]].
Anne Jefferson and Harry Lefferts pose for Rembrandt as part of a complex political situation.
==="Collateral Damage"=== : by Mike Spehar.
Hans Richter's flying instructor is still heartsore over his loss. He volunteers to fly a special mission to Paris targeting the unsuspecting Cardinal Richelieu.
==="Euterpe, Episode 1"=== :by Enrico M. Toro.
Composer [[Giacomo Carissimi]] is directed by Cardinal Mazarini (Mazarin) to visit Grantville, and finally obtains adequate funds.
==="The Company Men"=== :by Christopher James Weber.
The ambassador from the powerful [[Mughal Empire]] of northern India is held captive in Austria, but Grantville does not have enough troops to rescue him. Instead, Mike Stearns hires a mercenary troop run by an Englishman and an Irishman.
==="Just One Of Those Days"=== :by Leonard Hollar.
A string of mishaps keeps a Finnish cavalryman from action against the Croats attacking Grantville's high school, while an uptime German is uniquely positioned to pick off attackers.
==="God's Gifts"=== :by Gorg Huff.
Down-time German [[Lutheran]] pastor Steffan Schultheiss in Badenburg is wary of the citizens of Grantville shortly after its appearance due to their modern views on religion; in which he warns his flock against Grantville in order to keep their modern progressing influence from corrupting his congregation. However, Schultheiss's religious warnings were not heeded due to politics and economics both made Grantville attractive to Badenburg. Schultheiss continued to condemn Grantville's practices until his outcries infuriated his wife, who has a positive view on Grantville. Eventually, with guidance from his wife, Schultheiss changed his stance on Grantville and becomes more tolerated on the Americans' ideals, including [[freedom of religion]].
==="Bottom-Feeders"=== :by John Zeek
The story is a police procedural that follows two policemen Jurgen Neubert, a down-time farmer and former [[mercenary soldier]] turned cop, and Marvin Tipton, a long service cop, through a murder case.
==="An Invisible War"=== :by Danita Ewing
"An Invisible War" is a short novel that was the first serialized piece of longer fiction that spanned this and the next Gazette in their e-published versions—though the whole (110 pages) was published in the hardcover release of ''Grantville Gazette II''. The tale set mostly in 1633 after Grantville has had time to settle-in and look beyond immediate survival issues. It deals with public health and integration and dissemination of medical knowledge efforts during the end of the Confederated Principalities of Europe and early United States of Europe period, for the various Mike Stearns-led administration's have been repeatedly reminded by {{nowrap|[[List of 1632 fictional characters#Nichols, James|Dr. James Nichols]]}} and [[List of 1632 fictional characters#Mailey, Melissa|Melissa Mailey]] how vulnerable populations are and were to diseases in the seventeenth century era—so the up-timers have been both strategically aware and taking steps from the outset within their capabilities and resources to mitigate any preventable health problems beginning in the novel [[1632 (novel)|1632]]. To add impetus and urgency, as time goes by in the experience of Grantville, some of the historical research conducted in the two libraries reveals that plague outbreaks occurred locally in OTL in diverse regions during 1632, 1634, and 1635 saw a large epidemic-size outbreak. Worse, the historical record might also indicate other outbreaks, which were poorly documented.
The story is one of Grantville's medical personnel meeting head-on with down-timer University practices, prejudices and a college curricula based in large part on the [[Classics]] and [[theology|Theological]] studies. The town establishes the Lahey Clinic hospital near the Grantville High School and establishes a local nurse training program in 1631–1632, and by the summer of 1633 has reached out to the faculty of the University of Jena, but the only spareable medical manpower to head up a college of medicine are... women!
==Fact Essays==
==="A Quick and Dirty Treatise on Historical Fencing"=== :by Enrico M. Toro
==="So You Want To Do Telecommunications In 1633?"=== :by Rick Boatright
==="Mente Et Malleo : Practical Mineralogy And Minerals Exploration In 1632"=== :by Laura Runkle
==="The Secret Book Of Zink"=== :by Andrew Clark
==Literary significance and reception== A reviewer for Rosboch Book Reviews called the book "a mixed bag" with "some of the stories are cute, some are more serious."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.books.rosboch.net/?p=723 |title=Grantville Gazette II – Eric Flint (Editor) |date=May 16, 2011 |website=Rosboch Book Reviews}}</ref> Another reviewer at Goodreads called the book "A fun and quick read although the non-fiction articles can get pretty dry."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.goodreads.com/review/show/247259081 |title=Grantville Gazette II (Grantville Gazette, #2) |date=December 22, 2011 |first=T.J. |last=Blackburn |website=Goodreads}}</ref>
The Grantville Gazette II was listed on the [[Locus (magazine)]] Hardcovers Bestsellers List for a single month in 2006 at number 10.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.locusmag.com/2006/Issues/06LocusBestsellers.html |title=Locus Bestsellers, June 2006 |magazine=[[Locus (magazine)|Locus]] |date=June 2006}}</ref>
==See also== {{portal|Novels}} * [[The Grantville Gazettes]] — This article covers various common matters on the [[Spin-off (media)|sub-series]] in depth, in particular the Phase II experiments with an [[eMagazine]] and Phase III (ongoing) maturation of the milieu using [[collaborative fiction]]. All the Gazettes are edited by [[Eric Flint]]. *[[1632 characters]] — Historical and fictional characters *[[Development history of the 1632 series]]

{{Infobox person | name = Hans Hermann Adler | image = | alt = | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = {{birth date|1891|04|07|df=yes}} | birth_place = [[Cheb|Eger]], [[Austria-Hungary]] | death_date = {{death date and age|1956|03|29|1891|04|07}} | death_place = [[Wallerstein, Bavaria|Wallerstein]], [[West Germany]] | nationality = German | employer = [[Heidelberg University]] | organization = | occupation = Professor of [[Journalism]] | years_active = 1930s–1950s | known_for = | notable_works = }} '''Hans Hermann Adler''' (7 April 1891 – 29 March 1956) was a German professor of [[journalism]] at the [[University of Heidelberg]].
==Life== Adler was a graduate of the Humanist High School Eger in West [[Bohemia]]. After completing his studies of classical [[philology]] and history at the [[Charles University in Prague]], [[University of Innsbruck]] and [[Humboldt University of Berlin]], he received his Ph.D. from the [[University of Graz]]. He became a trainee at the {{ill|Johann Conrad Hinrichs|de|Johann Conrad Hinrichs|lt=J. C. Hinrichs}} bookstore in [[Leipzig]], a journalist and theater critic, and was editor of the [[Schlesische Zeitung]] in [[Breslau]] and the Oderzeitung in [[Frankfurt (Oder)]]{{as written|reason=This is not [[WP:PARENDIS]] this is the current official name of the city.}}. In 1932, he became a professor of journalism at [[Heidelberg University]], endowed by the {{ill| Verein Deutscher Zeitungsverleger|de|Verein Deutscher Zeitungsverleger}} (Association of German Newspaper Publishers). In 1933, after the dismissal of [[Hans von Eckardt]], he took over the director of the Institut für Zeitungswissenschaften (Institute for the Study of Journalism) as honorary professor, and received the privilege of "right to examine" (''Prüfungsrecht''){{efn|In German law, the ''{{ill|Prüfungsrecht|de|Prüfungsrecht (Deutschland)}}'' defines who has the right to examine candidates for professional certification or advanced degrees, and what rules they operate under.}} in the faculties of philosophy, political science, and economics at the University of Heidelberg. He became Director of its Interpreting Institute, and from 1941-45 had regular teaching duties as professor. During this time, he was a member of the editorial board of the "Handbuch für Zeitungswissenschaften" (Handbook for the Study of Journalism) and also authored some of its articles. Adler was a contributor to [[Hans Joachim Beyer]]'s Nazi periodical ''Auslandsdeutsche Volksforschung''.
Adler spent the last years of his life in Wallerstein in the [[Nördlinger Ries]] in [[Bavaria]] and promoted the {{ill|Egerländer Gmoi|de}}, an association of people from the [[Egerland]] region.
==Ancestry== The origin of the Adler family was in the old bourgeoisie of the Egerland, which since 1392 had held its ministerial seat at Treunitz at Eger (now Dřenice, Cheb). The Egerländer Adlers are probably descendants of the old Bohemian nobility of Adlar from the family of Janovice, which was named after the town of [[Janovice nad Úhlavou|Janowitz an der Angel]] (Janovice nad Úhlavou), which ultimately takes its name from a man named Johannes.<ref>This is documented in 1224, in the ''Codex diplomaticus et epistolaris regni Bohemiae''</ref> The Janovice and their descendants were historically important, and had a coat of arms featuring an eagle with a horizontal half-moon with clover leaf tips.<ref>See Roman von Procházka, ''Genealogisches Handbuch erloschener böhmischer Herrenstandsfamilien.''</ref>
==Literature== * ''Handbuch der Zeitungswissenschaften'', Leipzig, 1940 Anton Hiersemann Verlag * ''Heimatkreis Eger – Geschichte einer deutschen Landschaft in Dokumentation und Erinnerungen'', Amberg in der Oberpfalz, 1981 Seite 554 * Josef Weinmann: ''Egerländer Biografisches Lexikon mit ausgewählten Personen aus dem ehemaligen Regierungs-Bezirk Eger'', Seite 44, Männedorf / ZH 1985, {{ISBN|3-922808-12-3}} * Albrecht Ackermann: ''Das Institut für Zeitungswesen ( Zeitungswissenschaft ) an der Universität Heidelberg 1927 – 1945,'' in: Rüdiger vom Bruch / Otto B. Roegele: Von der Zeitungskunde zur Publizistik - Biographisch-institutionelle Stationen der deutschen Zeitungswissenschaften in der ersten Hälfte des 20. Jahrhunderts, Frankfurt am Mai, Haag & Herchen, 1986.
